content: I think that a lot of men recommend DFW to women because they sincerely want to appear to be intellectuals even when they aren’t. DFW’s vocabulary is vast, his style is (at times) endearing and less pretentious than that of the average writer with a vocabulary like his, and, to pseudo-intellectuals, the themes, and even the words themselves, are nearly incomprehensible. This compels many men to wear their “love” of DFW as a sort of intellectual plumage whether they understand him or what he’s trying to communicate or not. It’s usually an ironic vehicle for mansplaining, too, thanks to their lack of either actually reading the works or understanding them. I enjoyed many of his short stories but couldn’t really get into his novels. To be fair, my favorite novel is The Count of Monte Cristo by Dumas, so the length wasn’t the issue. It was the feeling of dragging along and, like you noted, the fact that there wasn’t much that I really related to on a personal level that could hook me in for the long haul. I didn’t care much for Catcher in the Rye either. Shhhhh don’t tell the literati. Thanks for sharing your experiences and especially for reminding us that outstanding female authors don’t have enough vocal proponents. My biggest takeaway from your article will be to recommend more female authors to everyone. If I must, I will do it over, and over, and over, and over, and over again until they finally read their works and report back to me. 😹😀
